climbs.name: Goldfish
climbs.fa: unknown, it's so close to Golden Wall. Someone must have done this

content.description: Start with your feet on a tiny rail, and do a left gaston on the foot long, vertical rail and your right hand on a decent sloper. Work your way right into the scoop with a knob at the top, moving feet on a few small holds. There's a decent size jug just before the top for the topout.
content.location: Look for the tiny rail for the start for feet and the vertical rail for the left hand start.Â

climbs.name: Carp Crack
climbs.fa: unknown. It's so close to Golden Wall, someone must have done this

content.description: Depending on your height, you can start with a sit, squat, or stand start. Shorter folks could go with stand or squat, while taller can get the most enjoyment from a sit start. For a squat / stand start begin with both of your hands in the widest part of the crack with your left foot on a little nubbin and your right foot in the crack. Work the crack with positive holds left until the crack switches to the right after the deepest section about two thirds up. Top out, and look behind you for a great view.
content.location: Get to the Golden Wall. With the wall on your right, keep walking up the trail, and this boulder will be on the right. This will be the first climb with the obvious crack on the left side of the boulder.

content.description: Golden Fin is a sunny boulder just to the left of the Golden Wall with a few easy routes. It is a great spot if anyone in your climbing party gets nervous about the highball routes on the Golden Wall.
